[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.Election/ElectionContract_Candidate.cs] [Function: SetCandidateAdmin()] [Access Control] Can the parliament default address forcibly change any candidate admin without permission checks, allowing governance to seize control of candidate operations at lines 27-28? [File: contract/AElf.Contracts.Election/ElectionContract_Candidate.cs] [Function: SetCandidateAdmin()] [Access Control] Can Context.Sender manipulate their ManagedCandidatePubkeysMap at lines 51-54 even if they are not the old admin, since removal happens unconditionally? (Medium)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.Election/ElectionContract_Candidate.cs] [Function: SetCandidateAdmin()] [DoS] Can an attacker cause denial of service by repeatedly calling SetCandidateAdmin to bloat the ManagedCandidatePubkeysMap with duplicate entries at lines 46-49? (Low)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.Election/ElectionContract_Candidate.cs] [Function: SetCandidateAdmin()] [State Inconsistency] If State.CandidateAdmins[pubkey] is set but IsCurrentCandidateOrInitialMiner returns false later, can this create orphaned admin entries that cannot be removed? (Medium)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.Election/ElectionContract_Candidate.cs] [Function: IsPubkeyBanned()] [State Manipulation] Can an attacker bypass banned status by using a pubkey variant not in BannedPubkeyMap (e.g., different case, encoding) at line 63? (High)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.Election/ElectionContract_Candidate.cs] [Function: IsCurrentCandidateOrInitialMiner()] [State Race] If CandidateInformationMap[pubkey].IsCurrentCandidate changes between check at line 77-78 and subsequent operations, can this create TOCTOU vulnerabilities? (Medium)
